segments.text: There were four children in Mother's family, so what she inherited from her family, then Dad doubled.
So they had inherited land, and Dad actually made the last payment on the land.
in December of 1969 and was dead in March of 70.
Right, so financially, your mother's family was better, in Texas lingo, better off than your dad's family.
Yeah, yeah.
But if I had asked your dad's father what he did for a living, would he have said ranching?
Farming?
I don't know.
They may have had a little plot of land here and there, but there was nothing handed down.
Was your dad the first to go to college?
Yes.
What about on your mom's side of the family?
Had either of her parents gone to college?
The mother was a teacher.
Her dad had like an eighth grade education.
But her mom was a teacher.
Her mom was a teacher.
Because I'm thinking there, again, is the typical America.
It was that generation that begins to make the difference in the educational level.
Same true in my family.
You're mom and dad's children.
Oh, most all of that generation.
All right.
So you were kind of excited about moving here.
Your mom's reaction, she came...
I can't really say I was really excited about coming.
I had really good friends in Austin.
Oh, okay.
And I had a boyfriend.
I'm not there for a boyfriend.
But once I got here, yeah.
And you were well-received.
Oh, yes.
All right.
And your mom, being a good wife, okay, if we're to move, do the best I can.
What were the activities in which she plunged once she got here?
You know, she had five children, and my brother Bob was tiny.
He had just been born.
He was born in 54, so he would have been... Oh, I hadn't thought about it.
He's a little kid.
He's little.
And...
So she really didn't have time to do PTA and a lot of that.
There were too many.
But what she did get into were all the things on campus.
The social club is still there.
Until she got sick, she really didn't miss meetings.
Who were her closest personal friends in those early years?
There was a group that wasn't in the very early years, but in a little bit after she'd been here for a while.
developed the Ladies Aid Society.
And it was Jean Graff and Frances Lindsey, Jim Lindsey's wife, and maybe Doris Hannigan and Minnie Pope Cherry.
The Cherries and the Hannigans, as couples with mother and dad, those three couples were good friends.
Now, that's Tom Cherry's wife.
Tom Cherry's wife.
Now, your dad brought from Austin... Mrs. Warren, the secretary?
No.
Oh, I forgot.
Or Meg Warren.
I'm not sure that she came immediately.
that she had helped him in the land office.
But I'm trying to think, went to Presbyterian Church, now deceased, who had been at the land office as the, as a fiscal.
Diebel.
Clark Diebel.
Clark Diebel.
Yeah.
Tell me about the, about Clark Diebel and your dad's relationship with him.
Yeah, I don't think I'm being much help to you, because I really, you know,
I think that our generation has included children much more.
And frankly, when I got there, I was so thrilled with all the activities at the high school.
So I was really kind of busy doing my thing.
All right, let's go to your dad's routine.
I know Dad had the highest respect for Clark Diebel.
I know there was a real bond there.
And I understand that.
that when to clean up the land office, that Clark was one of the key people in helping with that.
All right, as you recall your dad's schedule, normally he headed to the office about what time of day?
Early.
How early was early?
Do you remember things like that from when you were 16?
No, but was it?
I don't.
I don't know that he was there for breakfast.
And I assume school probably started at 8 o'clock.

One summer in Austin, before we moved here, when I was 14, when it was still legal to work that age, I interviewed, and I'm sure Dad had set it up, and I worked that summer, just to take a course in typing, and I worked at the TEA, Teachers Education Agency, that was housed in the same building, the old land office building where Dad lived.
And so that summer, he and I rode together, and I remember we went very early.
And we stayed, you know.
Was he home for supper most nights?
Most nights.
And do you remember his bringing a briefcase or a whole bunch of paper home?
No, because he was two blocks from the office.
He'd go back.
Okay, he'd go back to the office.
And do you remember his going back to the office many nights?
You know, isn't that awful?
I knew that.
I probably would not remember.
What about social events at the house?
Were there many?
There were.
There were, because it was a grand old place for entertainment.
And the staffing of the house, was there a cook?
A maid?
She was one and the same.
There was a man and a woman.
I started to say a couple, but that might imply more than it was.
And they sort of shared the duties.
When the board was in town, were you aware of a board meeting?
Not back then.
Because they would have been not far across the street.
Now, the fire occurred, the house burned when?
Are you home?
I was home for winter break from the University of Texas.
And I remember...
going off on an errand.
I think I may have given Mother a permanent that morning.
It was back when we did each other's home firms.
And coming back and all this activity had started and you could see smoke out of the ceiling.
Out the roof.
Now this was during the Christmas break?
January, yeah.
Oh, okay.
And what time of day?
It seems like the boys were going to, the ones who were still on campus, were going to Meals at Savisa.
And I just remember the windows in that old house went to the floor.
And I just remember furniture being passed through.
And I remembered stacks of dishes, and not one dish was broken.
And it was all literally just hand to hand.
So you're saying students and others?
Students and everything.
Mine was the back room and I had inherited from friends in Austin a lot of formals.
And I can remember the net just flying.
out the windows.
Do you remember in hindsight any special things that may have been lost?
Probably the pictures.
When I left Brady, we had autograph books.
And my little growing up friends, you know, we had autograph books and all those little pictures.
And I'm still friends with a lot, several of us that grew up together.
went to Santa Fe a couple years ago, and we still do things together.
And a lot of those were lost.
But no, in terms of financial value, the losses were moderate.
Really, maybe the main thing, Dad had sent me a doll during the war, and it had a real gold skirt.
And it was so fine, I was never allowed to play with it.
I could just look at it.
And that was lost.
But like, he didn't lose any heirlooms or any World War II items that were priceless.
There was some, like some of the, the crate that my doll came in that said, persists, that held a lot of the World War II mementos, made it through.
The cedar chest that Daddy built with his own hands, made it, you know, it was scarred, but it made it through.
And a lot of the stuff was in there.
And I was more fortunate than my brothers and sisters because I had clothes in the sorority house at Texas.
So I didn't lose everything.
Whereas my little sisters, Linda can, they remember.
In fact, she said it was the first time she can remember.
I think Lester's and Braley's stayed open.
And, you know, they went and picked out clothes because, I mean, they literally had none.
And so your feelings about the assistance that students, faculty, everybody else can give.
Oh, my goodness.
And I can remember standing in the yard, and Daddy was such a big man, and I always felt so safe up beside him.
And I can remember us standing there and just watching the flames come out.
All right, so you're away on an errand or something.
You come back, and it is beginning to burn.
I think the trucks were already there.
Okay.
Yeah.
So that it was an hour or so that it burns up.
Okay, and all of this is- Seems like it burned for a long time.
And it's all in daylight.
Well, it seems like when I can remember, my memory of Dad and standing in that backyard, it was getting dark, or maybe the smoke made it dark.
And it started up high around the chimney.
Apparently the mortar had deteriorated between the bricks and the big fire that George Washington, the black man who was helping them.
And it wasn't a terribly cold day, was it?

No, but it seems like when we got in the next morning, it must have rained overnight because every now and then the scent, the smell of the burned house that we went in and it either frozen or there was something wet that I can seem to remember going in the next day.
And so when they, quote, put it out, the shell of the house is left.
And where'd y'all spend that first night?
Over at the boardroom with Miss Cashin.
in the old border house just north of Sevesa.
And how long did your family stay there?
They stayed there for several weeks and ate in Sevesa.
And then the university bought the house on Lee Street where Mrs. Jessup lives now, Emily Jessup.
And then do you know anything about where the idea came from to build another house where they built it?
Mother says she and Doris Hannigan
walked and had something to do with picking the side out.
She could tell you better.
Now, I've heard the story that your dad said that he picked the precise angle.
Is that right?
That he wanted to be the first one on the campus to see the sunrise.
Can't you imagine him saying that?
I can.
I don't remember hearing that.
I remember hearing about he didn't want the...
You know, those gnarly old mesquite trees that are still there.
He refused to let those be cut.
And I remember him being very proud of the pediment over the front door, that he thought that was just fine.
All right, now that little gully out kind of in front of the house that you have to cut, do you know why that gully is there?
No.
That's where they dug the clay for the bricks for Old May.
Oh, my gosh.
And they made the bricks on site.
So that's one of them.
All right, now let's see.
Are those the same old bricks that then went back into the house?
Some of those did, yes.
Because there are old bricks used in that.
Yes, some of those did.
Oh, that's neat.
Who designed it?
Do you remember, did your mother or dad have anything to do with the design of the house?
Yeah.
Apparently a design was put forth maybe by some people in architecture, and I don't know names.
And it was a very modern house being in the early 60s.
And that was, I guess, not acceptable to a lot of people.
Excuse me.
So they worked with Dee Dee Matthews and Gene Donahoe.
What was it, a year or so before?
You know, I just, I'm trying to think.
It was more than a year.
I want to say they may have moved in in 65.
after the January 63 fire.
So that in square footage, the current President House may be smaller than the old one was?
I don't know.
I don't know.
I didn't have that feeling.
Oh, no.
The bedrooms were bigger upstairs.
And certainly it was finer.
Now, are you out of college by the time you move into the new house?
I guess I'm teaching in Houston.
So you never lived there.
What was your mom's reaction to the new house?
She absolutely loved it.
Absolutely loved it.
And they were able to use some of the furniture.
Downstairs, the old downless sofas with the down cushions were recovered.
And those had been saved from the fire.
And so there were a few things that are kind of in that formal front room.
But the furniture that they were able to buy.
And people were so kind to donate so much of the materials that were used that
But it just seemed like it was something everybody was proud to have.
Now, did your dad get involved much with the planning of the interior, or did you leave that to your mother?
You'll have to ask her, because I don't know.
But he was all... Dad, you know, with his degree in industrial education, I can remember him doing things like...
When we lived in Brady, there was a surplus of bunk beds.

So he bought bunk beds for, especially my sister's rooms, and then designed these headboards that slipped down over and you could put, you know, covered the whole things up so that they looked like these wonderful beds.
So he was really, he was, Dad could spot problems or spot things that needed to be.
I'm sure he was.
What were his hobbies, his recreations?
What did he do for fun?
I think friends.
Okay.
He didn't, he never golfed, to my knowledge.
We would walk a lot at night.
Oh, where?
Oh, well, I can remember visiting after they got into the new house.
And so we would walk from there then toward the main campus.
But from the old house, we would walk way out
to the west campus.
None of that was developed.
You remember the road was always full of pits.
But we would walk way, way out that way.
And he was not walking to inspect or check on people?
Oh, no.
No, no.
And who would go on the walk?
Whoever was there.
Would your mom go?
Sure.
Mother has always kind of had foot problems, so long walks were kind of not her thing.
They were some of my favorite things.
But you kids would go?
Uh-huh.
If y'all had a house guest, would some people?
Mm-hmm.
Now, I thought he hunted some.
He did, when we would go to the ranch, yeah.
But that wasn't that big of a thing?
Do you have friends who are hunters?
I'm sure you do.
Mm-hmm.
Dad was never like that.
And he didn't have a sit-down hobby, did he?
No.
He didn't collect stamps?
He loved, like, kind of a regular Sunday afternoon would be to go to church and then dinner and then maybe a little nap and then a long drive.
He loved to get out in the country and...
See what was blooming.
If there, on a Saturday, if there wasn't a football game, what would he do on a Saturday?
He had classes Saturday morning, I know, but the Saturday afternoon, Saturday evening.
I know.
Let's see, Methodist, you know, and you all went to the A&M Methodist Church.
And Pinky Downs usually came down and sat with us.
And he would bring Dad, I can still see, he would check stories, like if the story was here,
He would have these real hard, he would check all around the story that dad was told.
And he would bring newspapers.
And circle the story.
Now as far as you know, was your dad well acquainted with Pinky before y'all moved here?
I have no, see I don't know that.
My brother would come to football games with dad.
But I never did that, so I don't know.
All right, at the Methodist Church, you all went regularly.
Did you children have an option when you were in high school?
What if you had said, I don't want to go this morning?
When I had to, you're talking to the big sister that has one of those pins with all the bars for perfect attendance.
And truly, it started in Brady.
And I can remember sitting more with my grandmother in church than sitting with mother and dad.
But you're also demonstrating it never occurred to you not to go, did it?
No.
Same here.
Yeah.
We do.
What else do you do on Sunday morning?
And when my kids got to the point they didn't want to do that, I'd say, you know.
So the only thing I could do was hold lunch over their heads.
So Sunday school and church.
NYF.
In the early evenings was very important.
All right.
Did y'all have a Sunday night preaching then?
Mm-hmm.
James R.Q.?
Did you ever know James R.Q.?
Oh, yeah.
He was here, and he was wonderful.
Now, I heard a few people who thought
that in order to really make progress as an A&M administrator, you had to be a Methodist.
I heard that too.
I heard that too.
I guess there's always probably one church in a community that small that most people go to.
And as you were growing up, you can never remember when Texas A&M wasn't mentioned warmly.
Oh, our house in Brady.
I had maroon and white towels.
But A&M for years was just something I heard about.
Yeah.
And your brothers, it never occurred to them that they would have an option as to where they would go to school?
No.
No.
And really, you were asking about that when I got ready to go to college.
Dad said, really, sister, your choice is your TWU or Texas.
And that wasn't a tough choice at that time.
Do you remember going to Mustard's?
You know, I don't.
See, muster now is much bigger than it used to be.
Is that right?
Oh, see, Sterling Evans doesn't remember a muster before World War II.
I was really not encouraged to do university things.
I mean, I was a 16-year-old.
So, be who you are.
Absolutely.

uh very very good uh let's see uh and your mother of course although she had gone to the university of texas it she had been married to an aggie long enough that it had she had no emotional adjustment problem you know do you remember now you don't mention any names if you have any do you remember anybody any rudeness that your parents experienced when they got here
Oh, I couldn't imagine anybody being rude to my dad.
No, I have no recollection of that.
Now, you were saying that one of the kids said, Earl, we're here.
Do you remember any other teasing names that students or anybody else used to refer to your dad?
Because his name was James Earl, wasn't it?
Mm-hmm.
But I never heard anybody call him, refer to him as Jimmy or J-E. Only the Rangers, you know, in the service.
He was Jim or Big Jim.
Oh, really?
Yeah.
Yeah.
You know, because they go so strictly by your first name.
That's right.
Yeah.
So in the war, apparently.
Yeah.
At the time you all moved here, your dad was physically, what was he, six feet tall?
He was six feet.
Yeah, was he 6 or was he taller?
I don't know.
Maybe he was 6'2".
He was a big man.
By what would he have weighed?
Oh, very, probably 235.
Because I've heard him, two or three years later, I heard him refer to himself occasionally.
Potbelly present.
And I don't remember him having a potbelly.
Maybe I didn't observe, but I didn't.
So I always thought, well, he was trying to disarm everybody from not being too serious.
What do you think made him most proud of his years here?
What do you think he was?
I think the growth.
I think the growth was really important, and sort of the change in attitude.
toward A&M.
That, you know, when he came it was small and it was strictly military and that's why I'm sure he was chosen to come.
That's what I understand.
But he was wise enough to have the vision that it couldn't stay that way.
Do you particularly share with me, if you can, anything that you recall about his feelings on co-education and making a co-volunteer?
You know, I really don't.
And when I try to think of something specific to remember about how he felt, I think the way he would, wherever we were, he would introduce himself.
I'm Earl Gutter, I'm from Texas A&M.
And that almost, just his pride in that.
I'm.
Because I think I told you the other day, when I got back the first draft that I had written of the Aspirations Report that had those recommendations, he had some, he had some very tough questions.
Why this, why this, why that?
And I had assumed that he was wondering what those questions really meant is can we make it, can we get the board to approve it, can we get the people to support it?
I read nothing into it that he was saying I'm opposed to it.
And let me elucidate a little more on that.
There was a referendum soon after that
during that academic year, a referendum of the student body on these two questions.
Overwhelmingly, the students approved.
We're having a faculty meeting in the old chemistry lecture of arts and sciences
And your dad, as was his pattern, would speak to each of the college faculties once a year.
And this was Arts and Sciences Day.
And so we were not going to have a faculty referendum.
And we faculty were really uptight about that.
You know, why in the world?
And in his remarks, he didn't say a single thing about faculty referendum.
So there were questions and answers.
And they said, OK, now there's time for one more question.
I'm sitting in the next to back row, and I raise my hand, and I think it was Cooper recognized, and I stood up, and I was so frightened that my voice quivered.
And I said, you know, Mr. President, there's a referendum tomorrow for students.
Why aren't you having a faculty referendum?
And he then chuckled and said, hell, I don't need to have a faculty referendum.
I know y'all are all in favor of these things.
Everybody said, oh, yeah, yeah, yeah, meeting adjourned.
And as we walked out, most of my buddies walked by and said, where are you working next year?
Well, now we're about seven, eight years later.
This is the last session I ever had with your dad.
And I was in there begging for more money for the library, as chairman of the library committee.
And in the end of the conversation, I said, do you remember that question I asked you that day?
And he said, yes.
And I remember how frightened you were.
I was dumbfounded that his memory was that sharp.
Also, I want to mention to you, in that conversation, I then said...
He really had.
He really had.
I don't care how gruff he had to be to get stuff done, he did have such a tender heart.
And you see, some of us didn't know that for a while.
And I said, we're talking about all these changes.
I said, only you could have done it.
And he said, what do you mean?
Now, by this time, you know how you kind of sometimes sit around...
And he said, what do you mean?

I said, well, sir, they couldn't say you weren't a Texan, that you weren't an Aggie, that you hadn't been in the Corps, that you hadn't served your country, that you didn't work hard, that you didn't have a strong personal private life, that, you know, there wasn't any gossip or anything out there.
They couldn't say you didn't know your way around Austin and that you weren't acquainted with people named Connelly and Johnson and Teague and Pickle and things like that.
and that you were one of those fuddy-duddy PhDs from somewhere way off.
He leaned back and he said, oh, I never thought about any of that.
I said, oh, I'm sure you didn't.
Well, by then he was chocolate.
And did you sense in him satisfaction that progress was being made in the 60s?
No.
You have to remember, too, I finished high school in 1960.
I went three years to Austin and finished there.
I taught two years in Houston, and then I went to Massachusetts.
I taught there, and then I moved to Michigan.
But by then, the enrollment was going.
So my contact, especially after the mid-'60s, you didn't call like we do now.
We sure didn't travel like we do now.
So I really missed a lot of that.
And A&M was really, really making great progress during those days.
One of the big deals when I was teaching in Newton, Massachusetts, was Dad was going to be on, I think it was the Today Show, and was going to be interviewed by Sandra Van Oker.
And my principal made arrangements to have a TV so that I could watch Dad on national television.
And I've got a feeling that his confidence of doing that was about where yours was, asking that question.
He was so ill at ease.
Alright, now, what do you think of his duties until the
Which part of his duties do you think he enjoyed most and enjoyed least?
Most he probably enjoyed the students.
Okay.
Like he didn't enjoy speech making?
No.
He didn't enjoy speech making.
What about going to Austin and Washington to work directly with the key leaders?
Did he enjoy that?
You know, I never remember Dad complaining about anything that he had.
You know,
I never remember regrets.
I never remember spoken hate that just wasn't in his name.
If it was the job, you did it.
And I think I inherited that from him.
I think my kids have inherited that.
You know, you just... Life doesn't come to you on a platter.
And you just... Whatever the job is, you do it.
I have the impression that...
And I think one day he kind of referred to this in a brief conversation.
I have the impression that Governor John Connolly would sometimes chat directly with your dad about suggested board appointments.
I can remember when I was in Austin that dad would come and meet with Governor Connolly.
And I remember getting to go pick dad up one day and getting introduced to Governor Connolly and just being so charmed.
But for dad to then turn around and tell me at lunch what they talked about just was not his nature.
Because I have the impression that even the problems too, that he kept those inside.
I assume.
I assume.
